body:
> Or implement it ;)

I could be wrong, but I don't think a naked `.HasIndex` call will ever do anything on Cosmos. You're going to need to chain something (like `ForVectors`) to specify how it will be used in the index specification.

This definitely would require more thinking... You know more than me, but it seems like it could make sense to apply a Cosmos indexing policy that includes paths only to the properties on which HasIndex() has been called, no? One big difference from relational is that in relational, there are no indexes by default, whereas in Cosmos everything seems to be indexed by default, and the policy is more of a way to do finer-grained tweaking to only index specific properties.

In any case, probably not for 9.0, so yeah, validating against HasIndex() at this point sounds like the right thing indeed...

issue.title: Index convention changes for non-relational providers

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.body:
Block unused indexes with the Cosmos provider. Fixes #34023.

Also stop adding indexes for foreign keys by convention for non-relational providers. Fixes #34053.

issue.title: Cosmos: allow customization of the container's indexing policy

issue.body:
Are there any plans to add these provider-specific modeling indexing options:
  - included. Currently all properties are indexed `/*`. How about specifying composite indexes as well: e.g. (`/lastName,/firstName`)
  - excluded e.g. don't index on property `/nonce`
  - unique indexes

body: See #32517 for enabling proper support for HasIndex() on Cosmos.

issue.title: How do I handle: The Azure Cosmos DB provider for EF Core currently does not support index definitions.'

repository.name: efcore
repository.description: EF Core is a modern object-database mapper for .NET. It supports LINQ queries, change tracking, updates, and schema migrations.

issue.body:
Hello EF Core gurus,

I am trying to upgrade my project [AspNetCore.Identity.CosmosDb](https://github.com/MoonriseSoftwareCalifornia/AspNetCore.Identity.CosmosDb) to .Net 9, and I'm getting a new error message when I run the unit tests:

System.InvalidOperationException: 'The entity type 'IdentityRole' has an index defined over properties 'NormalizedName'. The Azure Cosmos DB provider for EF Core currently does not support index definitions.'

This error message I believe is coming [from this line in the designer](https://github.com/dotnet/efcore/blob/aed754c34a426afdc633c32f3d9f88a681e90c41/src/EFCore.Cosmos/Properties/CosmosStrings.Designer.cs#L167).

It looks like this is related to #34023.  The assumption with this is that since Cosmos ignores the model builder function that creates an index, that the Cosmos designer should throw and error.  In this case of my project, ignoring the index is just fine, and should not throw an error.  Perhaps this can have an option to convert this from an error to a warning?

The entity "IndentiyRole" is inherited from Microsoft.AspNetCore.Identity.IdentityRole, and it is there that the index is defined for the property NormalizedName. So this is something that is out of my control.

My question is this: Is there a way I can have the Cosmos DB provider "ignore" indexes so the error does not get thrown?  Or perhaps there is something in the EntityTypeBuilder that I can do to remove the offending index, or ignore it?

Thanks!

-Eric

body:
This has caused an unforeseen problem with by project.  See #35264 
Instead of throw an exception, how about throw a warning?

Another use-case for being able to include HasIndex would be in situations/applications where you want to allow the person installing your software to choose which database provider they wish to use.

Since EF Core supports SQL and NoSQL databases now, including CosmosDB it would make sense to ensure that developers can use all of the features & functionality of EF Core in their apps without restricting it with exceptions and other errors/warnings based on the specific provider.

My end customer should be able to install my software and select SQL Server, Postgres or Cosmos and EF Core should be able to handle it (as long as I don't do any direct usage of the database/SQL myself).
